etymologies: Old English begeondan, from be ‘by’ + geondan of Germanic origin (related to yon and yonder)

definitions: at or to the further side of

examples.text: he pointed to a spot beyond the trees
around half the passengers were in transit to destinations beyond Paris

shortDefinitions: at or to further side of

definitions: outside the physical limits or range of

examples.text: the hook that held the chandelier was beyond her reach
the land sloped away until far beyond sight it reached the Great Plains

definitions: more extensive or extreme than; further-reaching than

examples.text: the authority of the inspectors goes beyond ordinary police powers
what these children go through is far beyond what most adults endure in a lifetime

definitions: happening or continuing after (a specified time or event)

examples.text: many people work well beyond the age of sixty-five
we can manage another two years, but beyond that the system is not viable

definitions: having progressed or achieved more than (a specified stage or level)

examples.text: we need to get beyond square one

shortDefinitions: having progressed or achieved more than

definitions: above or greater than (a specified amount)

examples.text: absenteeism had gone beyond 15%

definitions: to or in a degree or condition where a specified action is impossible

examples.text: the landscape has changed beyond recognition
their integrity is beyond question

shortDefinitions: to degree where something is impossible

definitions: too much for (someone) to achieve or understand

examples.text: the questions were well beyond the average adult
I did something that I thought was beyond me
beyond telling us that she was well educated, he has nothing to say about her
there was little vegetation beyond scrub and brush

definitions: at or to the further side of something

examples.text: from south of Dortmund as far as Essen and beyond
a view of Hobart with Mount Wellington beyond
there was the terminal and, beyond, an endless line of warehouses
she blurs the boundaries between reality and what lies beyond

shortDefinitions: at or to further side of

definitions: more extensive or extreme than a particular point

examples.text: the athletes are pushing themselves to their limits and beyond

definitions: after a specified time or event

examples.text: music went on into the night and beyond

definitions: above or greater than a specified amount

examples.text: he could count up to a billion now, and beyond

definitions: the unknown, especially in references to life after death

examples.text: messages from the beyond
